verb.description: Cover (a piece of ground) with concrete, asphalt, stones, or bricks; lay paving over.
examples: the yard at the front was paved with flagstones

noun.description: A setting of precious stones placed so closely together that no metal shows.
A paved street, road, or path.

phrases: the proposals will pave the way for a speedy resolution to the problem
So does he think this project might pave the way for slightly offbeat buildings elsewhere in the city centre?
These will pave the way for more domestic participants in the retail sector.
Nevertheless, because it is cheap, it is paving the way for more and for worse.
The paper also paves the way for more Community Support Officers.
the proposals will pave the way for a speedy resolution to the problem

Nevertheless, because it is cheap, it is paving the way for more and for worse.

origin: French, literally paved, past participle of paver.
